title: No, malaria doesn’t kill 300,000 people in Nigeria a year, as insurance seller claimed
subtitle: Nigeria is Africa’s most populous country, but it doesn’t account for almost 70% of the world’s malaria deaths each year.
author: africacheck.org
vclaim:
• None Promoting the benefits of health insurance, tech start-up WellaHealth said malaria killed 300,000 people in Nigeria each year.
• None The World Health Organization says Nigeria is one of a number of countries where malaria cases are rising.
• None But the agency’s latest data shows that in 2017, there were 81,640 deaths from malaria in Nigeria; the lowest in seven years.

Conclusion: 81,640, not 300,000 lives, lost to malaria in Nigeria each year

To highlight the burden of malaria in Nigeria, a tech start-up said the disease killed an average of 300,000 people in the country a year.

The company said the number was from the World Health Organization. But the WHO’s most recent report estimates a much lower toll – 81,640 deaths in 2017.

But there is still work to be done to combat the mosquito-borne disease, as the rising number of malaria cases in the country shows.
